folder: Broadway and Union Square, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The Lincoln funeral procession on Broadway, at Union Square, as it is turning westward on 14th Street. The remains arrived at the Desbrosses Street Ferry on the 24th and were placed in state at the City Hall. Leaving the next day for a similar service at Albany, they were carried in the procession shown to the Harlem River Railroad Depot. The line of march was up Broadway to 14th Street, west on same to Fifth Avenue, up the Avenue to 34th Street, and west through 34th Street to 9th Avenue. A detailed account is to be found in the volume "Obsequies of Abraham Lincoln in Union Square, New York City" A N page 129.

April 25th, 1865

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Lincoln Funeral.

text:
Columbus Day Parade in 1892. Column shown moving west on 17th Street, into Union Square, West, thereform south to and west into 15th Street. General Schofield and staff are shown heading the parade.

October 12, 1892.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Columbus Day.

folder: 17th Street and Union Square, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Military Parade upon the occasion of Columbus Day, October 12th., 1892. A Connecticut Inf. Regiment is shown making a left column turn from Union Square East, into 17th., Street.

October 12, 1892.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Columbus Day.

text:
Union Square West, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of 17th Street.
About 1913.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - 17th Street.

text:
(1) Cocoanut, and cocoanut milk drink vendor, at Union Square South on the west corner.
June 5, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Another cocoanut vendor at the same location but viewed eastward.
May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another cocoanut vendor at the southwestern corner of Union Square. The photographers direction is northeastward and shows buildings upon Union Square East.
February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Food - Refreshment vendors - Fruit drinks.

text:
(1)

Communist Demonstration: 1934, No. 1. This demonstration takes place every year on May Day, in Union Square. All members of the Communist Party and its many branches (some of which are frankly Communist, such as the Young Communists' League, while others employ non-partisan titles), together with Communist sympathizers, are expected to turn out and demonstrate. As the Socialist Party also demonstrates in Union Square on May Day, clashes between
these bitter rivals are frequent.

May 1, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

Communist Demonstration: 1934, No. 2. A Spanish group of marchers.

May 1, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

Communist Demonstration: 1934, No. 3. The "League of Struggle for Negro Rights." This is a good example of a title chosen to attract non-Communists into a Communist organization.

May 1, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Communist Demonstrators

text:
Communist Demonstration: A set of three views of the school contingent making an eastward turn on East 17th Street from Broadway to pass the reviewing stand in the northern confine of Union Square.

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Communist Demonstration.

text:
Neg. No. 226 (C No. 2 and 3)

Communist Demonstration: Three views of the line of march turning eastward at Broadway and East 17th Street. Views 1 and 2 show an educational unit while No. 3, a medical group. Note the cooperation of the New York Police Department.

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Communist Demonstration.
